title: Ginger Spice Brownies
full_text:
Ginger Spice Brownies
Close
Jump to recipe
Prep
35 mins
Cook
40 mins
Cooling Time
30 mins
Total
105 mins
Serves
16 servings
Cook Mode
(Keep screen awake)
Ingredients
6
ounces
(170g; 12 tablespoons)
unsalted butter
3
ounces
finely chopped
dark chocolate
(85g; about 1/2 cup, about 70%
7
ounces
granulated sugar
(200g; about 1 cup)
1
ounce
dark muscovado sugar
(30g; 2 tablespoons). see note
3
large
eggs
, straight from the fridge
1 1/2
teaspoons
vanilla extract
2
teaspoons
grated peeled
fresh ginger
2
teaspoons
ground ginger
3/4
teaspoon
Diamond Crystal
kosher salt
; for table salt, use about half as much by volume or the same weight
1/2
teaspoon
ground coriander
1/2
teaspoon
ground allspice
1/2
teaspoon
freshly grated
nutmeg
1/2
teaspoon
instant espresso powder
, such as Medaglia d’Oro (optional)
1/4
teaspoon
ground
cardamom
1/8
teaspoon
ground clove
2 1/4
ounces
all-purpose flour
(65g; 1/2 cup)
2
ounces
Dutch-process cocoa powder
(60g; about 3/4 cup)
1 3/4
ounces
crystallized ginger
(50g; 1/2 cup), thinly sliced
Directions
Adjust oven rack to middle position and preheat to 350°F (180°C). Line an 8-inch square anodized aluminum baking pan with foil to cover the bottom and two sides, leaving overhang on the sides. If you like, grease lightly with pan spray.
Liz Voltz
In a small stainless steel saucier, melt butter over medium-low heat, stirring occasionally with a heat-resistant spatula. Bring to a simmer, then remove from heat and stir in chocolate; the mixture will seem quite thin. Set aside.
Liz Voltz
In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the whisk attachment, combine granulated sugar, muscovado sugar, eggs, vanilla, grated ginger, ground ginger, salt, coriander, allspice, nutmeg, instant espresso (if using), cardamom, and clove. Whip on medium-high until extremely thick and fluffy, about 8 minutes. (The whipping time can vary significantly depending on bowl size, batter temperature, and mixer wattage, so use the visual cues as your primary guide.)
Liz Voltz
Meanwhile, in a medium bowl, sift together flour and cocoa powder. When the egg mixture is fluffy and thick, reduce speed to low and pour in the warm chocolate-butter mixture. Once it is incorporated, add flour-cocoa mixture all at once and continue mixing until roughly combined. Finish with a flexible spatula, scraping and folding to ensure batter is well mixed from the bottom up.
Liz Voltz
Pour into prepared pan and tap firmly on the counter to even out the batter. Top with an even layer of crystallized ginger. Bake until brownies are glossy and just barely firm, about 35 minutes, or to an internal temperature of 205°F (96°C). (Take care that the probe is inserted at a sharp angle to avoid touching the bottom of the pan.) The timing of this recipe is based on anodized aluminum and will vary significantly with glass, ceramic, or nonstick pans, materials that will also affect the brownies' consistency.
Liz Voltz
Transfer pan to a wire rack to cool so that the crumb of the brownies can set, about 30 minutes. Slide a butter knife between the brownies and the sides of the pan that aren’t lined with foil; gently tug on the foil, then lift to remove the brownies from the pan. Cut into sixteen 2-inch squares. Serve or transfer to an airtight container with a sheet of wax paper between layers, and store for up to 1 week at room temperature.
Liz Voltz
Special Equipment
8- by 8-inch anodized aluminum pan, stand mixer, wire rack
Make-Ahead and Storage
Stored in an airtight container, with a sheet of wax paper between the layers, the brownies will keep about 1 week at room temperature.
Notes
Muscovado sugar is sold in many grocery stores; we prefer it for its rich molasses flavor and moisture content. If you cannot find muscovado sugar, dark brown sugar is a great substitute.
